name: AI-Powered Zendesk Support Responses with RAG, OpenAI, and Supabase Knowledge Base

user.name: Md Sagor Khan
user.bio: Building smart automations with n8n to save time and reduce repetitive work. I create ready-to-use workflows for businesses and creators who want to focus on what matters most.

description:
‚ö° How it works

This workflow automates first responses to new Zendesk tickets with the help of AI and your internal knowledge base.

Webhook trigger fires whenever a new ticket is created in Zendesk.

Ticket details (subject, description, requester info) are extracted.

Knowledge base retrieval ‚Äì the workflow searches a Supabase vector store (with OpenAI embeddings) for the most relevant KB articles.

AI assistant (RAG agent) drafts a professional reply using the retrieved KB and conversation memory stored in Postgres.

Decision logic:

If no relevant KB info is found (or if it‚Äôs a sensitive query like KYC, refunds, or account deletion), the workflow sends a fallback response and tags the ticket for human review.

Otherwise, it posts the AI-generated reply and tags the ticket with ai_reply.

Logging & context memory ensure future ticket updates are aware of past interactions.

------

üîß Set up steps

This workflow takes about 15‚Äì30 minutes to set up.

Connect credentials for Zendesk, OpenAI, Supabase, and Postgres.

Prepare your knowledge base: store support content in Supabase (documents table) and embed it using the provided Embeddings node.

Set up Postgres memory table (zendesk_ticket_histories) to store conversation history.

Update your Zendesk domain in the HTTP Request nodes (<YOUR_ZENDESK_DOMAIN>).

Deploy the webhook URL in Zendesk triggers so new tickets flow into n8n.

Test by creating a sample ticket and verifying:

AI replies appear in Zendesk

Correct tags (ai_reply or human_requested) are applied

Logs are written to Postgres

data.details:
The IF node can be used to implement binary conditional logic in your workflow. You can set up one-to-many conditions to evaluate each item of data being inputted into the node. That data will either evaluate to TRUE or FALSE and route out of the node accordingly.

This node has multiple types of conditions: Bool, String, Number, and Date & Time.

defaults.name: Answer questions with a vector store

parameters.notes: üîó Set this webhook URL as a trigger in your Zendesk account under 'Admin ‚Üí Triggers' so that new tickets are forwarded here.
üìö Replace with your own Supabase project credentials. Ensure you have a 'documents' table with embedded KB content.
üóÑÔ∏è Create a Postgres table `zendesk_ticket_histories` with fields for session context. This allows AI to recall past ticket interactions.
ü§ñ Add your own OpenAI API key in the credential settings. Adjust model if desired (gpt-4o, gpt-4o-mini, etc.).

parameters.name: content_en
parameters.description: Contains all KB articles to answer user questions accurately.

options.systemMessage: =You are a professional support assistant. Use only the retrieved knowledge base documents to answer the customer‚Äôs ticket clearly, formally, and concisely.

conditions.rightValue: will get back to you shortly

parameters.notes: üè∑Ô∏è Update `<YOUR_ZENDESK_DOMAIN>` with your Zendesk subdomain. Example: `https://mycompany.zendesk.com/...`

‚úÖ After setup, create a sample ticket in Zendesk to test:
- Does AI reply appear?
- Correct tags (`ai_reply` / `human_requested`)?
- Memory stored in Postgres?
If yes ‚Üí workflow is ready!
